column4: Every time I login, I need to do a 'sudo modprobe ndiswrapper' in order to get my wifi card working. Is there a way to fix this so it will automatically work when I turn on my computer?
there is... you want to learn about "run levels", and the '/etc/init.d/' magical directory hierarchy
i'll check it out, is there a quick way to do it?

basically, when your computer starts, it goes through various "run levels", which are "how much you can interact with it" in most systems, so on one of the lower levels, you could add a command to its start script to launch your custom thingy (e.g. modprobe or whatever)

if you poke around in '/etc/init.d/', you'll quickly see the general structure; then edit the appropriate 'rc' file as root (use sudo on your editor), and find a good spot... these scripts are shell-like, so if you know shell scripts (like batch files), you'll see the spot to put your command soon)
thanks
no worries
on my desktop intrepid, i have '/etc/init.d/rc' -- that's not necessarily *the* best file to use, but it's close, and maybe okay -- the experts can make a call here if they are at their keyboards :-)
looking through the file, it looks like code... while I can follow the logical structure, where should I put my command?
well, you want to find the runlevel that will be probably "before" X starts (usually that's a high number), and you want it there for your "command line only" level (single-user, i think it's called)
so maybe level 2 or 3... take a look at whatever handles those
i'm going to look at my 'rc'...
gah, I'm looking. I really should invest more time in learning linux directory structure.
yes, once you get a few important branches "inside your head", things go much smoother/faster :-)
near the end of the file is a 'rc.boot' mentioned... maybe that's the ticket?
maybe I should put the command in the /etc/rc.boot file?
precisely, that might get executed on every boot -- just what you want
